div1.p: Howard offers a justification of his characterization of Dean in his play, "Yellow Jack."

div1.head: Letter from Sidney Coe Howard to Walter De Blois Briggs, August 11, 1934
div1.p:
I am very glad indeed to have your letter about YELLOW
JACK and thank you for the fine things you say about the play.
I am sorry that you were thrown off by the Dean scene, because
it is one of the episodes which makes Lazear most attractive to
me. It goes without saying that I am a layman and not a doctor.
As such, however, I am deeply stirred by a man who ran the risk
of involving himself all but criminally to establish a truth of
such value to the mass of human kind. You are not interested,
however, in my reactions to that scene, any of which you must
have deduced from the fact that I wrote it. What you want, I
take it, is my historical justification for it. I have in my
files in New York a photostat of a pamphlet written by Agramonte,
who claimed to have been present at the time -- it may well be
the same to which you have reference. My impression from that
pamphlet was that Lazear had tricked Dean. My impression was
further substantiated by the fact that in Reed's case reports
only Dean's name is suppressed. You will find, if you look at
them, that he is always mentioned as “Private X.Y.” and it is
my impression -- though I should have to consult my notes to
make sure of this -- that Dean never did know how he got yellow
fever, due to the fact that he died he did not die before his identity ever
appeared in print. My faith in Dr. Agramonte's statement,
however, was shaken when one of the officers who cooperated in
the experiment told me, with substantial evidence to back up his
statement, that Agramonte had nothing whatever to do with that
episode and indeed little or nothing to do with any of the ex-
periment, that he stayed in his own laboratory in Havana City,
very seldom came out to Columbia Barracks and was neither liked
nor trusted by his associates. I have no authority for the
characterization I have given him in the play except the inalien-
able right of a dramatist to make any role as interesting as possible.
Returning, however, to the Dean episode: I asked Kissinger about
it and Kissinger told me that he had understood that Dean was not
infected in the laboratory but in barracks while he was asleep in
his bunk. Moran, on the other hand, claimed to know the details
of Dean's infection from Reed himself and to have learned them
during the time when he was in quarantine in Camp Lazear and earned
money from Reed by typing Reed's case reports for him. In other
words, I think I am substantially correct in the play's treatment
of the episode except that I included both Agramonte and Finlay
in the scene and I have no authority for Finlay's presence and
added it only because it helped me to write the scene and certainly
did no historical damage. I am sorry that the scene has caused
Dr. Lazear's family so much uneasiness. You need not, I think,
concern yourselves with the movies. They are most unlikely to
take any interest in a play which so assiduously avoids the
Bar Harbor, Maine
-2-
romantic note. In fact, de Kruif and I have insisted on our
supervision of any picture to be made from the play and have
thereby killed Hollywood's slight interest in it.
div1.closer: Faithfully yours, Sidney Howard. Walter de Blois Briggs, Esquire.
